Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Development of paired uranium-thorium and radiocarbon ocean ventilation records using deep-sea corals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ecology and biology of deep-sea coral ecosystems has seen increased research efforts in part because of human-induced impacts, including fishing activities. The importance of conservation efforts of deep-sea corals has amplified due to increased awareness of deep-sea corals as habitat-forming organisms for commercial and noncommercial fish species, their extremely long lifespans, and their potential as a climate archive. Developing independent means of determining the life-span and growth rate of deep-sea corals is important to assess their vulnerability and recovery rates from natural and human-induced disturbances. Equally important is the development of high-resolution age models of deep-sea coral archives. This project aims to examine the paleo-ecology of deep-sea corals by developing proxies in both the proteinaceous and carbonate skeletons of deep-sea corals in collaboration with Dr. Steward Fallon at the Australia National University in Canberra, Australia. Access to the laboratory, equipment, and dating methods provided at ANU, will create an opportunity to expand knowledge and understanding of deep-sea corals.

Development of paleoceanographic proxy measurements in deep-sea corals has moved beyond the range of potential promise in terms of reconstructing ocean ventilation rates. Records of ocean ventilation are used to determine how ocean chemistry has changed throughout geologic time, helping predict future climate change. This project will apply a novel uranium-thorium (U/Th) dating method paired with radiocarbon dates to develop age and growth rate records of black corals, Leiopathes sp. and cup corals, Desmophyllum sp. Pairing independent chronometers, such as U/Th dating with radiocarbon dating, allows for the reconstruction of ocean ventilation rates dating back to the Last Glacial Maximum (~20,000 years). The project will take a multiple proxy approach; pairing U/Th, radiocarbon, and neodymium isotopic measurement to reconstruct changes in surface, intermediate, and deep-water circulation patterns. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed research project applies uranium thorium (U/Th) and radiocarbon (14C) dating methods in order to develop age and growth rate records of the deep-sea coral, Desmophyllum sp. collected from Norfolk and Baltimore Canyons, located in the Mid-Atlantic region of the United States. Desmophyllum sp., a solitary scleractinian deep-sea coral whose skeleton is composed of aragonite, a new archive extending observations of ocean dynamics and the associated climate changes to periods well before onset of instrumental records.  Pairing independent chronometers, such as U/Th dating with radiocarbon dating, allows for the reconstruction of ocean ventilation rates dating from the Holocene (~10,000 years ago) back to the Last Glacial Maximum (~20,000 years). The overall goal of the project is to examine the paleo-ecology of deep-sea corals by developing geochemical proxies in the carbonate skeletons of deep-sea corals to assess their vulnerability and recovery rates from natural and human-induced disturbances.

            As a fellow for the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes Fellowship hosted at Australia National University the PI completed reconnaissance radiocarbon dating of forty-two live collected and sub-fossil deep-sea corals to determine their ages, which ranged from modern to 800 years ago. Trace elements including, uranium (U/Ca), phosphorous (P/Ca), barium (Ba/Ca) along with a novel method of measuring boron isotopes were also measured in the deep-sea coral skeletons using a laser ablation system coupled to both a Neptune Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) and Varian ICP-MS in order to develop a multiple proxy reconstructions of the Mid-Atlantic Ocean’s pH (boron isotopes), carbonate ion chemistry (U/Ca), and nutrient profiles (Ba/Ca and P/Ca). Providing evidence that the laser ablation method to determine the chemical composition of the coral’s skeleton is sufficient to previously established solution methods for boron isotope proxy development. Developing deep-sea corals as an archive for multiple proxies provides a unique opportunity to determine changes n the Mid-Atlantic Ocean depths of 500 meters to 1300 meters. Overall, the outcome of the project provides fundamental data for the PI’s master’s thesis project providing opportunity to continue research in a professional program.


Last Modified: 03/02/2015
Modified by: Mackenzie E Schoemann
